title: Jeptha Bradley
text:
Jeptha Bradley (December 31, 1802 – June 8, 1864) was a mid-1800s <a href="Vermont">Vermont</a> political figure who served in several elected and appointed offices, including <a href="Vermont%20Auditor%20of%20Accounts">Vermont Auditor of Accounts</a>.
Early life.
Bradley was born in <a href="Fairfield%2C%20Vermont">Fairfield, Vermont</a> on December 31, 1802. He studied law and was admitted to the bar, afterwards establishing a practice in Franklin and <a href="Grand%20Isle%20County">Grand Isle</a> Counties. A <a href="Whig%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Whig</a>, From 1835 to 1839 Bradley served as <a href="Sheriff%23United%20States">Sheriff</a> of <a href="Franklin%20County%2C%20Vermont">Franklin County</a>.
Start of political career.
Bradley later moved to <a href="St.%20Albans%20%28city%29%2C%20Vermont">St. Albans</a> and served in local and county offices including <a href="Justice%20of%20the%20peace%23Massachusetts.2C%20Connecticut.2C%20Vermont">Justice of the Peace</a> and <a href="High%20Bailiff%23Vermont">High Bailiff</a>.
He was appointed Inspector of <a href="United%20States%20Customs%20Service%23History">Customs</a> for the station in <a href="Alburgh%2C%20Vermont">Alburgh</a> in 1845. In 1847 Bradley was named <a href="Postmaster">Postmaster</a> in <a href="Highgate%20Springs%2C%20Vermont">Highgate Springs</a>.
Additional activities.
Bradley was active in the <a href="Episcopal%20Church%20%28United%20States%29">Episcopal</a> church, and served as a Delegate to the 1822 and 1850 annual state conventions.
In 1844 Bradley received a <a href="patent">patent</a> for an improved air-heating <a href="Furnace%20%28house%20heating%29">furnace</a>.
Bradley was one of the founders of the Horticultural Society for the Valley of Lake Champlain in 1850.
Later political career.
In 1849 Bradley was elected county <a href="Probate%20Judge">Probate Judge</a>, serving until 1850.
Bradley served as Register of <a href="Probate">Probate</a> from 1850 to 1852, and again in 1854.
He became a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> when the party was founded in the 1850s. In 1860 he was elected State Auditor by the <a href="Vermont%20General%20Assembly">Vermont General Assembly</a>, and served until his death.
Death and burial.
Bradley died in St. Albans on June 8, 1864. He was buried at Greenwood Cemetery in St. Albans.
